text.headline: Agriculture
text.text: Close relationships between railroad companies and the United States government propelled Euro-American settlement of Indigenous lands and a facilitated a transition from subsistence farming to producing commodities for expanding markets in the East and abroad. Less arid than the far West and less dependent on cotton and slavery than the South, the Midwest proved crucial in producing crops and meat for growing urban populations in the United States and Europe. Emerging agricultural networks often provided economic benefit to owners of railroads, factories, and packing houses. At the same time, farmers in the Midwest routinely organized to maximize their own benefit and combat corporate power. The impact of industrial agriculture continues to shape the economic and cultural realities of farming into the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries.

text.headline: Indigenous Agriculture
text.subtitle: "Guarding the Corn Field," Watercolor by Seth Eastman, 1853 | Catalog Link
text.text: Well before European arrival on the continent, Indigenous groups in the Midwest farmed corn, squash, and other crops. For example, this painting by Seth Eastman depicts Dakota women discouraging blackbirds from eating a crop of corn by clanging pots and making noise. Agriculture functioned as one part of broader Indigenous foodways that included hunting, gathering, and fishing.

text.headline: The Reaper
text.subtitle: Valley of the Upper Wabash, Indiana, 1838 | Catalog Link
text.text: The invention of the reaper and other farming implements facilitated the transition from localized, subsistence farming to the mass production of crops for distant markets. In order to succeed in market-driven agriculture, farmers needed to purchase plows and other equipment with their own capital or, more riskily, on credit.

text.headline: Communication and Education
text.subtitle: Prairie Farmer, 1852 | Catalog Link
text.text: The market revolution of the nineteenth century coincided with a communication revolution. With the invention of the telegraph, mechanically powered printing technology, and steam-powered transportation on waterways and rail tracks, information could travel more quickly. Farmers in the nineteenth century benefited from increasingly accessible educational and trade journals and periodicals, such as the Prairie Farmer, which was "devoted to western agriculture, horticulture, mechanics and education."

text.headline: Commodity Crops
text.subtitle: North America: Its Agriculture and Climate, 1857 | Catalog Link
text.text: An observer from the United Kingdom created this map in 1857, showing corn and wheat emerging as primary crops in the Midwest. In contrast, the East and South are portrayed as being focused on cotton, sugar cane, and rice with some wheat and less corn.

text.headline: Railroads Selling Land
text.subtitle: Choice Farming Lands in Iowa and Nebraska, 1871 | Catalog Link
text.text: After the United State government removed Indigenous people from their lands, by force or treaty, they then sold land to railroad companies at a low price. Railroad companies in turn would then sell land adjacent to the railroad at a profit, marketing specifically to Euro-American settlers.

text.headline: "You are Ready for Work"
text.subtitle: Choice Farming Lands in Iowa and Nebraska, 1871 | Catalog Link
text.text: Advertisements for land in the Midwest emphasized the likelihood of making a profitable living farming, even for people of modest means. Next to a list of costs involved in starting a farm, the pamphlet asserts that "many, who are now successful and wealthy farmers, commenced with barely capital enough to secure their land, and obtain some kind of shelter for their families."

text.headline: Map of "Choice Farming Lands"
text.subtitle: Choice Farming Lands in Iowa and Nebraska, 1871 | Catalog Link
text.text: The land sold by the Iowa Railroad Land Company paralleled Prairie Creek running east-west across present-day Iowa. Railroad construction responded to the natural landscape and drove Euro-American settlement with the support of the United States government.

text.headline: Farmers Organizing
text.subtitle: "Pro Rata," ca. 1876 | Catalog Link
text.text: Farmers in the Midwest routinely organized against the inconsistent  shipping rates set by railroads, as in this 1876 statement criticizing higher freight rates on "the weaker, or connecting branches" as opposed to the lower rates on the "stronger of main line of the road." Not coincidentally, the Midwest became a stronghold of Populism and its challenge to eastern railroad business interests. In this way, the market capitalism and transportation networks that fueled Euro-American settlement in the Midwest in turn motivated a formidable populist challenge.

text.headline: Flour and Grain Shipments
text.subtitle: Annual Statement of the Trade and Commerce of Chicago, 1870 | Catalog Link
text.text: As the nineteenth century progressed, the production of goods like flour and grain rapidly increased. The crops farmed in the hinterlands of the Midwest traveled to Chicago across railroad networks and were in turn transported to eastern markets for consumption.

text.headline: Brewing Industry
text.subtitle: Western Brewer, 1877 | Catalog Link
text.text: Other grains like barley fueled a growing brewing industry in the Midwest, particularly in Wisconsin. The consumption of alcohol—often in taverns—played an important role in the cultural networks of urban immigrant communities in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. It also became a target of a temperance movement that culminated in Prohibition.

text.headline: Meatpacking
text.subtitle: Annual Report of the Packing of the West , ca. 1870s | Catalog Link
text.text: Following similar networks as grains, animals were shipped from rural areas of the Midwest to Chicago, where they were slaughtered and packed for shipment to the East. Railroad investors and meatpacking house owners often gained tremendous wealth from the industry, whereas small farmers and meatpacking laborers often made minimal profits and wages in comparison.

text.headline: Refrigeration
text.subtitle: Icing Refrigerator Cars in Lincoln, Nebraska, 1948 | Catalog Link
text.text: The rapid growth of the meatpacking industry depended on the development of refrigerated cars that could transport perishable meat across long distances. Here, workers in Lincoln, Nebraska deposit ice into a compartments on top of railcars, allowing for the cold air to sink and cool the products inside.

text.headline: Dairy Industry
text.subtitle: Vedell Dairy, Knoxville, Illinois, 1948 | Catalog Link
text.text: The Midwest dairy industry remained highly localized into the early twentieth century, with small farms like Vedell Dairy delivering milk and other dairy products to customers who lived nearby. In the second half of the twentieth century, the dairy industry became increasingly dominated by fewer, larger dairy businesses with the capacity to distribute to broader markets.

text.headline: Images of Farming
text.subtitle: Farm ABC, 1954 | Catalog Link
text.text: The historic realities of agriculture in the Midwest involve forced Indigenous migration, economic hardships associated with commodity farming, and necessary cooperation to combat powerful business interests. However, images of farming in the twentieth century—like this children's book published in Racine, Wisconsin—often depicted an idyllic identity of farmers as white, self-reliant, and connected to nature.

text.headline: Transition to Industrial Farming
text.subtitle: Atlas of Clay County, Minnesota, 1964 | Catalog Link
text.text: The growth of large-scale, industrial agriculture in the late twentieth century moved even farther away from imagined ideals of the family farm. The consolidation of farms under corporate entities has utilized economies of scale to increase production and profit.

text.headline: Land Conservation
text.subtitle: Minnesota Peatlands, 1978 | Catalog Link
text.text: At the same time that industrial farming expanded across the Midwest, questions of sustainability challenged the primacy of agricultural output and profit. In contrast to draining the Black Swamp in Ohio in the nineteenth century—an effort that emphasized agricultural development over conserving wetlands—efforts to preserve the peatlands of Minnesota and the broader Great Lakes region has signaled an alternative approach to human interactions with the Midwest landscape.

text.headline: End of map
text.text: Go to next map:
